summaryOfNewsArticle: In a brazen daylight robbery at the Louvre museum in Paris, French police discovered that eight high-value jewels were stolen in just eight minutes by a professional gang believed to be part of an organized crime network. Experts, including Dutch art detective Arthur Brand and jewellery historian Carol Woolton, suggest the stolen items were dismantled and broken into smaller pieces to be sold for a fraction of their value, with the gold and gems possibly melted or cut down to evade detection. The theft is thought to serve financial motives such as money laundering, with one specific piece—the crown of Empress Eugénie—being dropped and recovered. Experts estimate the total value of the stolen items could reach £10 million, with large flawless stones potentially worth £500,000 each. Despite hopes that the items might one day be recovered, experts believe they are likely already in circulation, sold to untraceable buyers. The incident has deeply shocked the French public, who view the stolen items as part of their shared cultural heritage.
title: Where are the Louvre jewels now and can France get them back?
